titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William David Sherman Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:53

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The William David Sherman papers contain correspondence, writings, and other materials documenting the personal and professional activities of American author William David Sherman. Correspondence in the collection consists chiefly of incoming letters from English-language authors and literary scholars active during the mid to late twentieth century, including Asa Benveniste, Basil Bunting, Cid Corman, Robert Creeley, Rachel Blau DuPlessis, David Goodis, Bill Griffiths, Jeremy Hilton, Lyn Lifshin, Susan Smith Nash, Frances Presley, and Tom Raworth. The largest correspondence files are from Corman and Griffiths, poet and curator of the Eric Mottram Archive at King's College, London. Griffiths's letters, for example, discuss literary matters, the literary scene in England, and life in northeastern England. Writings consist chiefly of drafts of poetry collections, but there are also novels, short stories, copies of Sherman's graduate student work at SUNY Buffalo, and offprints for articles by other writers. Other materials include audio and video recordings, computer disks, subject files, photographs, and printed materials.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English; some materials in Spanish.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from David J. Holmes on the Alfred Z. Baker, Jr. and Stanton Francis Kennedy funds, 2005 and 2007.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 3 and 13 (computer disks): Restricted Fragile Material. Reference copies of electronic files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Boxes 7-9 (audiovisual material): Use of original is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The William David Sherman Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: William David Sherman Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, identified as a unique grouping and titled according to year of acquisition.

Descriptive information found in the Collection Contents section is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: William David Sherman (1940-)
bioghist.p: William David Sherman, American author, educator, and publisher, was born December 24, 1940, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to Louis and Gertrude (Benn) Sherman. Sherman was educated at Temple University (B.A., 1962) and SUNY Buffalo (M.A., 1964, Ph.D., 1968), after which he taught as an instructor and lecturer at various institutions in the U.S and Great Britain over most of the next two decades before settling in French Polynesia.
Biographical information taken from "William David Sherman." Contemporary Authors Online . Detroit: Gale, 2001. Gale Biography In Context . Web. 8 June 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The William David Sherman papers contain correspondence, writings, and other materials documenting the personal and professional activities of American author William David Sherman. Correspondence in the collection consists chiefly of incoming letters from English-language authors and literary scholars active during the mid to late twentieth century, including Asa Benveniste, Basil Bunting, Cid Corman, Robert Creeley, Rachel Blau DuPlessis, David Goodis, Bill Griffiths, Jeremy Hilton, Lyn Lifshin, Susan Smith Nash, Frances Presley, and Tom Raworth. The largest correspondence files are from Corman and Griffiths, poet and curator of the Eric Mottram Archive at King's College, London. Griffiths's letters, for example, discuss literary matters, the literary scene in England, and life in northeastern England. Writings consist chiefly of drafts of poetry collections, but there are also novels, short stories, copies of Sherman's graduate student work at SUNY Buffalo, and offprints for articles by other writers. Other materials include audio recordings, computer disks, subject files, photographs, and printed materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two groupings: 2005 Acquisition and December 2007 Acquisition.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: Correspondence, Writings, and Other Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 2005 Acquisition contains correspondence, writings, and other materials. Correspondence consists chiefly of incoming letters from English-language authors and literary scholars active during the mid to late twentieth century, including Asa Benveniste, Basil Bunting, Cid Corman, Robert Creeley, Rachel Blau DuPlessis, David Goodis, Bill Griffiths, Jeremy Hilton, Lyn Lifshin, Susan Smith Nash, Frances Presley, and Tom Raworth. The largest correspondence files are from Cid Corman and Bill Griffiths, poet and curator of the Eric Mottram Archive at King's College, London. Griffiths's letters, for example, discuss literary matters, the literary scene in England, and life in northeastern England. The correspondence also includes letters from friends and acquaintances in Moorea, French Polynesia, where Sherman resided in the early to mid 1990s.

The writings include corrected holograph drafts for poems, stories, and essays by Sherman, and several offprints for articles by other writers. Other materials include printed ephemera relating to Sherman and Shreela Ray.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from David J. Holmes on the Alfred Z. Baker, Jr. Fund , 2005.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: Writings, Audiovisual Materials, and Other Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The December 2007 Acquisition contains writings, correspondence, and other materials. Writings, arranged alphabetically by title, consist chiefly of drafts of poetry collections, but there are also novels, short stories, and copies of Sherman's graduate student work at SUNY Buffalo, including his thesis, "The Hero as Athlete" (1964), and dissertation, "The Contemporary American Novel" (1968).

In addition to writings, there are audiovisual materials, computer disks, correspondence and subject files, photographs, and printed materials. The audiovisual materials consist chiefly of audio recordings (on reel-to-reel and cassette tapes) of interviews, readings, and events, with Sherman and others. The computer disks appear to contain drafts of writings.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from David J. Holmes on the Stanton Francis Kennedy Fund , 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents on this audiotape reel include a reading of "Asphodel, That Greeny Flower" and music from artists such as Linda Ronstadt, Jackson Browne and Johnny Cash.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A written note accompanies this audiotape reel. It reads: Dear B and B, The reading of "Asphodel" is none too good, but it's there if you want it. "Romanze d'Amour" is for Barbara, and "Lost at Sea" is Bill's presidential campaign song! Guess you'll prefer the second side...Love and peace, Domi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Songs on this audiotape reel include "All Along the Watchtower" and Knockin' on Heaven's Door"...for Bill and Barbara. Detailed notes on the songs and their meaning are included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The audiocassette contains a list of contents. It includes songs from "Return of 'One Take Willy'" performed by 'Scratch Band'. The first three songs from "Keeping It Live" were performed at Family Folk Night, Clifton Green School, Salford by the new braken band. Dom Williams performed at The Eagle and Child, Whitefield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A written note on the back of a photograph came with this audiocassette. It is dated July 25, 1984, London and reads: Dear Bill, Just up north for a week hope your well although sometimes I wonder if that's not a silly question. I have been meaning to put this in the post for ages. Thanks for letter with the cheque that I will send it back or use it for a bookletbut cash it I will not. This tape needs updating but will work on a new one all a rush at the moment. Sue is well. Love, Ulli and Sue
